pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:0.5: 27. The long training rule on weavers
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.2: At that time a man who was going away said to his wife, “Weigh some thread, take it to the weavers, have them weave robe-cloth, and put the robe-cloth aside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.3: When I return I’ll give it to Venerable Upananda.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.4: An alms-collecting monk heard that man speaking those words.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.5: He then went to Upananda the Sakyan and said, “Upananda, you have much merit.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.6: In such-and-such a place I heard a man, as he was about to go away, tell his wife to have robe-cloth woven so that he could give it to you when he returned.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.8: And the weaver was Upananda’s supporter too.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.9: Upananda then went to that weaver and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.10: “This robe-cloth that you’re weaving for me, make it long and wide. And make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.11: “Venerable, they’ve already weighed the thread and given it to me, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.13: I won’t be able to make it long, wide, or closely woven.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.14: But I’m able to make it well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.15: “Just make it long, wide, and closely woven.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.16: There won’t be any lack of thread.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.17: Then, when all the thread had been used up, that weaver went to that woman and said, “Madam, I need more thread.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.18: “But didn’t I tell you to weave the robe-cloth with that thread?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.20: But Venerable Upananda told me to make it long, wide, and closely woven.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.21: And he said there wouldn’t be any lack of thread.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.22: That woman then gave him as much thread again as she had done the first time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.23: Soon Upananda heard that that man had returned from his travels, and he went to his house and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.24: That man approached him, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.25: He then said to his wife, “Has the robe-cloth been woven?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.27: “Please bring it, I’ll give it to Venerable Upananda.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.28: She then got the robe-cloth, gave it to her husband, and told him what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.29: After giving the robe-cloth to Upananda, he complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.30: “These Sakyan ascetics have great desires; they’re not content.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.31: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.32: How could Venerable Upananda go to the weavers and specify the kind of robe-cloth he wanted without first being invited by me?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.33: The monks heard the complaints of that man,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.34: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.35: “How can Venerable Upananda go to a householder’s weavers and specify the kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.36: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.37: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.41: “Foolish man, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.42: And still you went to the weavers of an unrelated householder and specified the kind of robe-cloth you wanted without first being invited.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.43: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.44: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.45.1: ‘If a male or female householder is having robe-cloth woven by weavers for an unrelated monk and, without first being invited, that monk goes to those weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.46: ‘This robe-cloth that you are weaving for me, make it long and wide; make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.47: and perhaps I will even give you a small gift;’
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.48: then, in saying that and afterwards giving them a small gift, even if it is only a bit of almsfood, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.2: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object, he wishes to give to the monk.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.4: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.6: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.8: any woman who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.12: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be transferred to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.16: the monk for whom the robe-cloth is being woven.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.18: without it first being said, “Venerable, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth should I get woven for you?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.20: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.21: Specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.22: “This robe-cloth that you are weaving for me, make it long and wide;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.23: make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.24: and perhaps I will even give you a small gift.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.25: Then in saying that and afterwards giving them a small gift, even if it is only a bit of almsfood—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.27: rice porridge, a meal, non-staple food, a bit of bath powder, a toothbrush, a piece of string, and even if he gives a teaching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.28: If the weaver makes it long or wide or closely woven because of the monk’s statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.29: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.30: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.31: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.32: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.33: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth for which I went to the weavers of an unrelated householder and specified the kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.34: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.37: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.38.1: If the householder is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.39: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.40: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.41: If the lay person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.42: If the lay person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.43: If the lay person is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.46: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.47: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.48: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.49: if someone wants to have expensive robe-cloth woven, but he has them weave inexpensive robe-cloth instead;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.51: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.52: The seventh rule, the long training rule on weavers, is finished.
